title: Trump Vows to Meet Hollywood on Tariff Plan That Shook Industry
content:
President Donald Trump said he would meet with Hollywood executives after confounding the US film industry over his plan to impose a 100% tariff on movies made overseas. 
“So we’re going to meet with the industry,” Trump said Monday afternoon. “I want to make sure they’re happy with it, because we’re all about jobs.”
Film and entertainment figures on Monday struggled to interpret Trump’s directive, posted to his social media account on Sunday evening, which said the American movie industry is “DYING” and cast foreign films as a national security threat that spread propaganda to US audiences.
“WE WANT MOVIES MADE IN AMERICA, AGAIN!” Trump said.
Shares of Netflix Inc., Paramount Global, Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. and other media and entertainment companies slid as Wall Street and Hollywood tried to discern what aspect of filmmaking would qualify for such tariffs and why it should be targeted like other industries. (Source: Bloomberg)

content: Halfway into a four-year tenure, President Bola Tinubu’s push to reform the floundering economy of Africa’s most-populous country has received the most significant thrust yet: An overhaul of tax laws, some that date back to Nigeria’s colonial past.

title: Eurovision Fans Find Swiss Franc’s Latest Surge Hits a Sour Note
content: As many as half a million fans heading to Basel for the Eurovision Song Contest next week are about to discover that Swiss prices stoked by the franc’s gains are far from music to their ears.

title: China’s Consumer Deflation Extends as Tariffs Take Toll
content: China’s consumer deflation extended for a third month in April as punitive tariffs imposed by the US add to a drag on prices from weak domestic demand.

title: ECB Needs Steady Hand and Mustn’t Overdo Rate Cuts, Schnabel Says
content: The European Central Bank needs a “steady hand” and mustn’t lower borrowing costs too much as inflation could turn out to be higher in the future, Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel said.

title: Trump Says 80% China Tariff ‘Seems Right,’ Ahead of Talks
content: President Donald Trump floated an 80% tariff on China ahead of negotiations due to begin Saturday as he urged Beijing to do more to open their markets to US goods.

title: Flock of Fed Speakers Show No Eagerness to Consider Rate Cuts
content: On a day when more than half of the Federal Reserve’s policymakers offered public remarks, not one made it sound like the US central bank was near lowering interest rates.

title: Argentina Halts Private Bond Sale Amid Pressure on Peso Rate
content: Argentina’s central bank intervened to stop a dollar bond sale by Banco Supervielle halfway through the trading day on Friday, according to two people with knowledge of the matter, a move that could avert pressure on the peso in the parallel exchange market.

title: US Official Meets With Mexico Bankers on Cartel Financing Risks
content: A US Treasury Department official made an unannounced visit to Mexico’s annual banking convention to discuss stepping up efforts to combat organized-crime finances.

title: Fed Governor Michelle Bowman Hires Staffers From Goldman, Davis Polk and BPI
content: US Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman, who’s on track to become vice chair for supervision, has turned to the banking world for three staff picks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Trump Says 10% Tariff Baseline Unless ‘Exceptional’ Offer Made
content: President Donald Trump said that he would “always” impose a minimum 10% tariff on trading partners — before quickly adding that “there could be an exception,” underscoring the difficulty discerning the US approach to dozens of trade deals under negotiation.

title: Bessent Says Debt Limit Measures Could Run Out in August
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told US lawmakers that his department’s ability to use special accounting maneuvers to stay within the federal debt limit could be exhausted in August.

title: Seattle Businesses Take Canadian Cash at Par to Lure Sports Fans
content: For years, the arrival of the Toronto Blue Jays in Seattle brought a familiar sight: tens of thousands of exuberant Canadians pouring into the city to cheer on their baseball team.

title: Mexico Finance Chief Says USMCA-Protected Exports Bolster Growth
content: Mexico’s finance chief Edgar Amador said the North American free trade agreement should continue to bolster the economy despite the threat that the US could push for major changes to it.

title: IMF Approves $1 Billion Pakistan Payment Over India Protest
content: The International Monetary Fund’s executive board on Friday approved a roughly $1 billion loan disbursements to Pakistan, bringing some relief for the nation’s fragile finances amid its worsening conflict with neighboring India.

title: US Stocks End Week Lower as Investors Look Ahead to China Talks
content: US stocks closed little changed Friday to notch a small weekly loss as traders weighed comments from President Donald Trump suggesting that an 80% tariff on China seemed right, just as negotiations between the two countries are set to begin on Saturday.

title: Ghana’s Credit Rating Raised by S&P After Spending Cut Plans
content: Ghana’s credit rating was raised by S&P Global Ratings after the new administration unveiled plans to rein in spending as the West African nation recovers from a painful debt restructuring.

title: Ghana’s Debt Burden Seen Falling Sharply on Economic Expansion
content: Ghana’s debt burden will ease sharply this year as the economy expands and the government reins in spending after a debt crisis, Barclays Plc said.

title: Warsh Suggests Fed’s Tariff Remarks Imply Impaired Credibility
content: Kevin Warsh, who is seen as a possible contender to be the next Federal Reserve chair, suggested the US central bank would be at fault if it cannot prevent tariff-related price hikes from leading to a persistent rise in inflation.

title: Trump’s Priority List for Tariff Talks Homes In on Around 20 Economies
content: The Trump administration’s first trade talks involve an eclectic mix of major exporters and smaller economies, as the White House looks to rack up agreements that could serve as models for other negotiations.

title: What to Know About the US-China Trade War as Talks Begin
content: The future of one of the world’s biggest trading relationships hangs in the balance after US President Donald Trump escalated the tariff war with China by imposing steep duties on imports from the country.

title: Options Traders Flock to Wager That Fed Won’t Cut Interest Rates
content: A contrarian wager that the Federal Reserve won’t cut interest rates this year is exploding in the options market.

title: Weak Jobs Report Raises Odds of Bank of Canada Cut in June
content: Canadian jobs data point to the start of a period of rising unemployment, and markets are betting the Bank of Canada is more likely to restart interest rate cuts in June.

title: Five Factors to Think About When It Comes to Tariffs and Inflation
content: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.

title: Waller Signals Firing Fed Officials Would Be Bad for US Economy
content: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said economic stability is improved when monetary policymakers are both accountable to voters and have job security.

title: Swiss Want a ‘Level Playing Field’ in Trade Deal With US
content: Switzerland held what it said were “constructive” trade talks with US officials Friday while indicating that negotiations can’t be all about concessions to Donald Trump’s administration.

title: US Farm Economy Is Starting to See First Hits From Trump Tariffs
content: Donald Trump’s tariffs are upending crop trading, delaying tractor purchases and constraining imports of chemical supplies into the US.

title: Officials, Airlines to Talk Newark Reductions After Outages
content: Airlines and aviation officials plan to meet on May 14 to discuss further flight cutbacks at Newark airport following multiple breakdowns in radar systems.

title: Newark Airport Hit by Another 90-Second Radar Outage
content: Air traffic controllers guiding planes in and out of Newark Liberty International Airport briefly lost communications and radar displays early Friday morning, the second outage in as many weeks affecting the transportation hub.

title: Trump Opens Door to Tariffs on Commercial Aircraft, Engines
content: The Trump administration is probing whether imported aircraft, jet engines and parts represent a threat to national security, a precursor to imposing new tariffs targeting the commercial aerospace industry.

title: US Official Meets With Mexico Bankers on Cartel Financing Risks
content: A US Treasury Department official made an unannounced visit to Mexico’s annual banking convention to discuss stepping up efforts to combat organized-crime finances.

title: Kohl’s Board Fight Spills Out After Director Departure
content: Kohl’s Corp. said on Friday the recent departure of a board director was related to a disagreement with the company — an abrupt change in stance from a day earlier and the latest sign of turmoil at the beleaguered retailer.

title: Hedge Funds Soured on Oil as OPEC Agreed to Bumper Supply Hike
content: Hedge funds turned the least bullish on Brent crude in about six months as OPEC+ agreed to a second major production increase, inflaming concerns that the extra supply could lead to a global glut.

title: Tufts Grad Student Öztürk Is Freed on Bail in Trump Setback
content: A federal judge freed a Turkish graduate student on bail while she fights possible deportation over the Trump administration’s claims of antisemitism in an op-ed she helped write.

title: Sarepta’s Week Goes From Bad to Worse on FDA Fears, Outlook Cut
content: Sarepta Therapeutics Inc. capped its worst week in four years as disappointing earnings and regulatory fears hit the drugmaker’s shares.

title: Oil Rises as Focus Shifts to US-China Trade Talks After UK Deal
content: Oil rose as algorithmic traders fled short positions amid renewed optimism about trade talks between the US and China this weekend.

title: Nestle to Raise Prices of Some US Chocolate on High Cocoa Costs
content: Nestle USA is increasing prices for some chocolate products due to commodity costs, a sign that sweet treats will stay expensive for consumers in the near term.

title: US Measles Cases Surpass 1,000 as Texas Infection Rate Slows
content: The US has confirmed 1,001 measles cases since the outbreak began in January, even as the virus’ spread in the hardest-hit state has slowed.

title: Stellantis Nears CEO Decision With US Boss a Top Contender
content: Stellantis NV is approaching the end of its complicated search for a new chief executive officer, with Americas boss Antonio Filosa emerging as the leading candidate, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: CoreWeave in Talks for $1.5 Billion Debt Deal 6 Weeks After IPO
content: Less than two months after a heavily scaled down initial public offering, CoreWeave Inc. is in discussions to raise about $1.5 billion in debt, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: San Francisco Train System Shut for Hours After Computer Issue
content: The San Francisco Bay area’s largest train system shut down for about four hours Friday after a computer problem, leaving thousands of workers across the region without access to a critical commuting option.

title: Santander Rejected Bid of About £11 Billion for UK Unit, FT Says
content: Banco Santander SA rejected a bid worth between £10 billion ($13 billion) and £12 billion for its UK retail bank from NatWest Group Plc earlier this year, according to the Financial Times.

title: Costco Makes Deal With Affirm Giving Shoppers Payment Plans
content: Costco Wholesale Corp. is tapping Affirm Holdings Inc. to let the retailer’s online shoppers pay over time for a transaction, an option that’s been helping many merchants sell bigger-ticket items and gives consumers more comfort in buying them.

title: Bankrupt Federal Contractor Seeks Fast Sale to Avoid DOGE Threat
content: A federal contractor that filed bankruptcy earlier this week during the latest round of government cutbacks asked a judge to approve a quick auction because of the ongoing threat of Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency.

title: Post Office Names FedEx Director Steiner Postmaster General
content: The United States Postal Service has selected FedEx Corp. board member David Steiner to be the country’s next postmaster general, the agency announced on Friday.

title: Zepbound Patients Fear Losing Coverage After CVS Deal for Wegovy
content: Allison Stange lost 40 pounds since starting Zepbound in April 2024, improving both her blood pressure and sleep apnea. Now she fears a deal struck between CVS Health Corp. and Novo Nordisk A/S will undo all that progress.

title: Germany’s New Finance Minister Backs Commerzbank Independence
content: Germany backs Commerzbank AG as an independent firm, Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil said Friday, indicating that opposition to the bank’s potential takeover by UniCredit SpA won’t abate under the country’s new government.

title: JPMorgan to Rent 20 Floors in Historic Buenos Aires Office Deal
content: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is expanding its footprint in Argentina with new office space, marking one of largest corporate rental properties over the past two decades in the nation’s capital.

title: Boston Celtics Investors to Decide Whether to Stay or Go
content: The Celtics and their investors have some big decisions to make now that they’re down 0-2 to the Knicks.

title: Fiera Tumbles on 50% Dividend Cut as CEO Desjardins Steps Down
content: Shares of Fiera Capital Corp. plunged by as much as 10.4% after the company chopped its dividend in half, as founder Jean-Guy Desjardins steps aside as chief executive officer to make way for Maxime Menard.

title: German Investor Deka In Exclusive Talks to Buy Dublin Office Block
content: German investor Deka Immobilien is in exclusive talks to buy a prime Dublin office building, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Air Canada Lowers 2025 Outlook as Travel to US Declines
content: Shares of Air Canada soared by as much as 13% Friday morning as the airline reported a lower — but better than expected — profit forecast for 2025 as President Donald Trump’s trade war slows the economy and discourages some Canadians from traveling to the US.

title: Traders’ Guide to US Stocks Most Affected in China Trade Talks
content: US equity investors will be watching closely as trade talks kick off between the Trump administration and China, with trillions of dollars hanging in the balance for American companies.

title: Sweetgreen Says Tariffs Led to Sharp Decline in Dining Out
content: Sweetgreen Inc. cut its annual guidance, citing a sharp decline in consumer sentiment following the announcement of new tariffs in the US.

title: Italy’s Banks Display Earnings Strength Amid Deal Wave
content: A group of banks involved in a series of deals reshaping Italy’s finance industry posted profits that beat estimates, highlighting the industry’s strength.

title: India's Swiggy Bleeds Cash in Quick-Commerce War With Blinkit, Zepto
content: Swiggy Ltd. reported a wider-than-expected loss as the Instamart quick-commerce business rapidly expanded its store footprint in the hyper-competitive segment.

title: Why Trump’s Auto Tariffs Are Poised to Drive Up Car Prices
content: President Donald Trump is betting that tariffs on imports of vehicles and automotive parts will bring more manufacturing to US shores.

title: Conservative Host Scorched For Setting The Bar 'Extremely Low' On Trump
content: Ben Ferguson called for the president to get more "credit" for his take on a "nonpartisan issue."

title: Rove, founded by a 22-year-old, is helping Gen Z earn airline miles without credit cards
content: During his junior year study abroad, Max Morganroth, traveled to 30 countries, primarily flying in business and first class. His jet-setting was funded

title: Is credit card debt forgiveness smart for seniors? Here's what experts think.
content: Debt forgiveness can provide relief for some seniors, but it's important to know when it is and isn't a wise move.

title: Trump slams Newsom after California governor proposes federal film tax credit to "Make America Film Again"
content: President Trump slammed Gavin Newsom on Tuesday, just hours after the California governor asked for collaboration on a massive national film tax credit.

title: Credit Suisse to pay $511M for helping Americans evade $4B in taxes
content: Credit Suisse has pleaded guilty to criminal charges and agreed to pay $511 million for helping wealthy Americans hide more than $4 billion.

title: The AP Will Not Change Nick Ut's Credit on 'Napalm Girl' Photo
content: The AP has released an extensive report looking at whether Nick Ut is the author of the Vietnam War Napalm Girl image.

title: Royal Credit Union partnering with local non-profits for diaper drive
content: Donations will be accepted between May 1 and May 31, 2025.

title: Newsom suggests tax credit for Hollywood after Trump proposes tariffs on foreign films
content: California Gov. Gavin Newsom reached out to the Trump administration on Monday with hopes that the two can pair up and create a $7.5 billion federal film tax credit to help out the movie business.

title: How holding rates steady affects you
content: From credit cards and mortgage rates to auto loans and savings accounts, all sorts of consumer borrowing costs are impacted by Fed moves.

title: Credit Suisse fined for helping rich Americans hide over $4 billion from the taxman
content: A Credit Suisse unit has pleaded guilty to US charges of helping ultra-wealthy Americans evade taxes and will pay a fine of more than $510 million.

title: SEC’s Anti-Fraud Public Service Campaign Warns Investors About Relationship Investment Scams
content: The SEC’s Office of Investor Education and Advocacy unveiled its anti-fraud public service campaign, which warns investors about the devastating impact relationship investment scams can have on their financial future.

content: April is Financial Literacy Month, and the SEC is encouraging investors to utilize the agency’s saving and investing resources on Investor.gov.

content: The SEC&#039;s Crypto Task Force will hold four more roundtables in its ongoing series discussing crypto asset regulation.

content:

content: The SEC&#039;s Crypto Task Force will host a series of roundtables to discuss key areas of interest in the regulation of crypto assets.

content:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the members of the Crypto Task Force staff, which is advising the Commission on matters related to crypto.

title: SEC to Host Roundtable on Artificial Intelligence
content: The SEC will hold a roundtable discussion on artificial intelligence and examine the risks, benefits, and governance of it in the financial industry.

title: How Embedded Finance Is Quietly Transforming Startup Business Models
content: Traditional banks are having a hard time keeping up with customers' expectations for embedded finance. In this guest commentary, Arthur Azizov, founder and investor at B2 Ventures, provides some answers to what customers want and why they want it.

title: Tariffs And The Venture Value Chain: A Blip Or Long-Term Pain?
content: Guest author Rohit Yadav takes us on an exploration of the value chain — VC fundraising, startup fundraising and exits — to see how tariffs are driving both direct and indirect impacts.

title: The Longer IPOs Delay, The Less Likely Debuts Will Happen
content: Over the past couple weeks, as we’ve seen Klarna, StubHub and others delay scheduled pre-IPO roadshows, it appears markets are to blame. But how will delays affect a company's success when it finally makes its debut?

title: Crypto Startup Ripple Buys Hidden Road For $1.25B
content: Crypto payments firm Ripple is acquiring brokerage house Hidden Road for $1.25 billion in one of the biggest M&A deals ever in crypto.

title: Tariffs, Volatility And The Startup Exit Dilemma
content: Even seasoned startup investors today face what feels like a novel turn of events: a potential recession and increasing exit uncertainty due to government-induced volatility, writes guest author Don Butler of Thomvest Ventures.  For an ecosystem that has long awaited the return of robust exit volumes, the uncertainty in the markets sparked by tariffs couldn’t come at a worse time.

title: CoreWeave Closes Flat In First-Day Trading
content: Shares of CoreWeave closed flat at $40 on their first day of trading on the Nasdaq today. Shares had opened at $39 on Friday, a day when the Nasdaq sank 2.7%.

title: CoreWeave Shrinks IPO
content: Cloud computing startup CoreWeave is cutting the size of its IPO, looking for a valuation closer to $23 billion than the roughly $30 billion it had originally targeted.

title: Want To Sell Your Startup Quickly To A Strategic Buyer? Consider This From The Get-Go
content: Whether buying a startup or selling one, there are plenty of steps that need to be considered, writes guest author Murat Abdrakhmanov. In this commentary he provides recommendations to help both buyer and seller reach their strategic and financial goals.

title: The Most-Active, Spendiest Startup Investors Are Lagging Greatly In Lucrative Exits
content: The most active, highest-spending startup investors are leading a lot of large new rounds lately. When it comes to exits, however, things look much, much slower. We used Crunchbase data to examine IPO and M&A exits since 2023 for six firms that regularly top our active lead investor rankings.

title: Forget Startups. Maybe The Most Adaptable Companies Are Those That Last Centuries
content: Building a lasting business can take an exceedingly long time, but it's nothing compared to hundreds of well-known, successful organizations and brands that can trace their roots back not in years or decades but in centuries. Here's a look at a few of them.

title: With Turo Withdrawal, A Slim IPO Pipeline Gets Thinner
content: Peer-to-peer car rental platform Turo became the latest venture unicorn to withdraw plans for a public offering.

title: Adapting The IPO Roadmap For Today’s Market
content: The path to IPO has become slower and more arduous for companies looking for an exit, writes Fiunder Shield's COO Carl Niedbala. In this guest commentary he lays out some effective measures to help founders be prepared when an opportunity presents itself.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.

title: Looking Back 10 Years, Seed Investors Envisioned A Different Future Unfolding
content: Reviewing old seed funding data is a lot like going into the past to see what people thought the future would look like. Going back roughly 10 years ago, it seems OpenAI was the company every seed investor should have backed, but who knew how times would change for the intended nonprofit.

title: Global Venture Funding Slowed In April, Despite Strong AI Showing
content: Global venture funding totaled $23 billion in April 2025, flat year over year and down significantly month over month from $68 billion invested in March, Crunchbase data shows.

title: How To Leverage Your Pre-Seed Funding For Rapid And Successful Growth
content: After the pre-seed round is a time for a startup to plan for securing follow-on investments, says guest author Sergei Bogdanov, who shares early-stage funding advice to founders regarding what to do as well as what not to do.

title: Most-Active Startup Investors Spent More In Q1
content: The busiest venture backers upped their game in the recently ended first quarter. Among the 14 most-active post-seed investors, a majority backed more deals in Q1 2025 than they did a year ago.

title: Europe’s VC Funding Stayed Flat In Q1, Even As Healthcare Added A Third
content: Europe’s venture funding plateaued at $12.6 billion in Q1 2025 — flat quarter over quarter and year over year, Crunchbase data shows. Without the sort of outsized AI funding rounds seen in North America in the first quarter, the continent’s share of global funding also fell.

title: Latin America Startup Funding Fell Sequentially In Q1
content: Latin America startup investment declined sequentially in the first quarter of this year, driven by a drop in later-stage dealmaking. Even so, funding was above the depressed levels seen a year ago, and early-stage dealmaking showed signs of strength.

title: SignalFire Closes On $1B To Invest In Applied AI
content: Bay Area-based SignalFire, a data-driven venture firm, has raised $1 billion for its fifth and largest fund, which it will invest in applied AI companies.

title: North America Startup Investment Spiked In Q1 Due To OpenAI, But Seed And Early Stage Fell
content: Despite several big deals that buoyed the numbers, North America early- and seed-stage investment declined to multiquarter lows in Q1, and reported round counts fell across stages.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.

title: 7 Deadly Pitch Deck Sins, According To A VC
content: VC firms receive thousands of pitch decks a year and a typical investor will spend no more than two to three minutes assessing each one. In this guest commentary, investor Michael Tefula of Ada Ventures shares seven of the biggest mistakes that are more likely to land your pitch in the “no, thanks” rejection bin.

title: Far Fewer Seed-Stage Startups Are Graduating To Series A — Raising The Risk Of Failure
content: Companies stalled at the seed stage might be sacrificing growth to get to breakeven, which could further hinder their ability to show the traction needed to get to a Series A.

title: Q1 Global Startup Funding Posts Strongest Quarter Since Q2 2022 With A Third Going To Massive OpenAI Deal
content: Overall, the first quarter of 2025 marked the strongest one for venture investment since Q2 2022. Funding was up 17% quarter over quarter from the $96 billion reached in Q4 2024.
